description:
Stop by Yemen Kitchen? Ya-man!

It was my first time having Yemeni food and never thought I'd categorize it as one of my comfort foods, but here we are. Yemen Kitchen is the epitome of a hole-in-the-wall, with only three tables. Though you definitely wouldn't go for its interior design, the authenticity of the establishment is palpable through its savory aroma, the Arabic music, and of course the food. The generous portions of tender Lamb Aqdah, roasted Chicken Kabsah, aromatic pilaf, and fresh from the oven Tawa Bread made me nostalgic for and teleported me back to a time I've never lived through and a place I've never been. I imagined eating these dishes around a dinner table, surrounded by warm chatter with people I loved. Happy is an understatement, and safe is a closer description to how I felt (even in the middle of the Tenderloin).

On top of the mouth-watering food (I'm actually salivating thinking about it right now), the cook may have been one of the nicest person on this planet. Because he was the only one running the kitchen and register, the service took a little longer than what you'd expect from a casual place as such. But as you hear the pan sizzle as he prepared your food expertly on the spot, you can't help but know that the wait will be worth it.

Pro tip: you can order ahead online through various apps or their website to save yourself the wait. They also do delivery! There's NO question that you must pay Yemen Kitchen a visit.
author: Claire W.

description:
Absolutely fantastic! 

I spotted this place driving by and though, hmmmmm.... I haven't had Yemenese food before. 

We just ordered for delivery and am blown away by the flavors and freshness. 

We ordered the Lamb dinner: 
Delicious yellow rice topped with a vegetable stew and flavorful and crispy lamb

The favas beans were amazing too
author: Mitra K.

description:
This place is truly a gem in SF. A for sure hole in the wall. Yemeni food is served here. I've had the famous Yemen dish and the chicken sandwich both were sooo good!! The dishes here have the right flavor! I'm deducting one star since it takes a while to make.

The location it's not the best area to be around in the night so I recommend coming during the day.

Also this place is best for take out since it only holds about 8 people. A must try for sure!
author: Shabnam N.

description:
This week, I started IF (intermittent fasting) and I'm also trying to give up white rice, white bread, and pasta...all the things that give me life.

Besides wanting to Hulk smash through every pastry case in San Francisco and stick my head into a rice cooker, I keep of thinking about my meal at Yemen Kitchen.

My co-worker and I ended up here by total accident. Plan A for lunch was unexpectedly closed and this was the closest place within walking distance. Praise the Yelp app!

Yemen Kitchen is the epitome of a hole-in-the-wall restaurant. It's run by one man, who's the owner, chef, and server. It's located in the seedy TL, a bit grimy, seats 8-9 people max, and the wall menu is only in arabic. 

I love that - the BEST ethnic places are the menus that I can't read!

Don't worry, they have a laminated menu in English too: https://bit.ly/2Ixaql9. The menu is meat centric with lots of lamb and chicken options but there's also options for vegetarians and vegans. Most items are roasted or stir-fried. Nothing is over $17. Cc's accepted.

I love Middle Eastern food but this was my first time having Yemenese food. This is the second Yemen restaurant in SF...the owner of Yemen Kitchen opened the first Yemen restaurant in SF (called Yemeni Restaurant) in Lower Nob Hill but sold it. 

We started with the Beef Stir Fried w/ hummus ($15): https://bit.ly/2tMjUDr which was excellent! The stir fried beef was tender and robust with spices while the hummus was creamy with a nice chunky texture. This completely blows South Bay's Oren's Hummus' out of the water on any day. 

Make sure to order a side of the Tawah Bread ($2): https://bit.ly/2Mq8tsM for sopping up all that bomb ass hummus. The tawah is a Yemeni bread that's like a thick paratha with tons of deliciously crisp layers. 

For our main, we shared the Roasted Lamb w/ potatoes, rice (Lunch - $13, Dinner - $16):  https://bit.ly/2MwlQrA. The roasted lamb shoulder was meaty and tender. While muted in flavor, the accompanying housemade green and red chili sauces were like crack. They were perfectly spicy and tangy which added a nice pop to the dish. The rice...ahhh, basmati rice and nicely spiced stewed potatoes were the ideal accompaniment for a deliciously satisfying Yemenese comfort meal. 

The owner accidentally charged us the dinner price for the entrée so he gave us each a complimentary square of Pistachio Baklava: https://bit.ly/2Kvx9TE. It was on point - flaky, sweet, and nicely sticky. 

Since it's a one man show and everything is cooked to order, expect to wait about 15 minutes for your meal to be prepared...longer during the lunch and dinner rush (especially with delivery orders via Eat24, UberEats, GrubHub, PostMates, DoorDash). 

The ambiance? There's none...it's tight quarters with 2.5 tables. The food is the focal point. Personally, I think this would be a great first date place...to see if that person can appreciate good food or if they're high maintenance AF.

Bourdain was right...

While we weren't on vacation, other than being on a 1 hour vacation from work: "Sometimes the greatest meals on vacations are the ones you find when Plan A falls through."
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
With so many bougie overpriced restaurants in San Francisco, it's nice to find a delicious hole-in-the-wall deal.  The specials are written on a chalk board in Arabic, so you have to rely on the laminated English menu.  There's only about 3 tables in this tiny storefront that is mostly kitchen.  And you'll definitely pass by some Tenderloin realness to get here.  But wow, the food is totally worth it!

Saltah: This is obviously the benchmark dish one must try when eating at any Yemeni restaurant for the first time and it did not disappoint!  Super tender morsels of lamb at the bottom along with a few errant potato pieces.  Tons of broth that was closer to gravy in texture and richness.  A must for helping get through all that bread.  But it's the fenugreek foam on top that really sets it apart from other Middle Eastern meat stews.  I mean saltah was using foam techniques way before fancy restaurants started foaming anything they could think of.

Tawah Bread: This is huge!  Like if you want it to compare to Indian bread, it's 3 times the size of a standard naan.  But with many more flaky layers than a naan, almost like a thicker version of a Malaysian roti.  Anyway, it was just perfect for the saltah.
author: Adam B.

description: Liver breakfast is very good, served all day. People working here are very nice. Tea is sweet and delicious. Prices are good, as are portions. Open late. I walked in after 10pm and the guy insisted I sit and enjoy while he closes down in the back. So welcoming. Five stars.
author: Emily F.

description:
Amazing food with reasonable price. One of the only Yemeni places in SF and food is super authentic. The restaurant itself is a hole in the wall in Tenderloin but is very safe to go during the day. The place is a bit small but cozy and special with Yemeni decorations. The menu is written in both Arabic and English - a sign that food is super authentic. People from local Arabic community often come here to chat and socialize. Very friendly vibe.

Me and my friend ordered Lamb Aqdah and Saltah (national dish of Yemen) along with Tawah bread. Lamb Aqdah is a spice-full lamb stew with potato and string beans. Lamb is super tender and soft and the spices are just right to blend with the lamb and vegetable. Saltah is a lamb soup also with some vegetable, with some pepper purée on top. The flavor isn't as strong as Lamb Aqdah, but the light pepper purée blends perfectly with the heavy lamb soup, making it a perfect dish for a chilly day. Tawah is Yemeni bread - multi-layer and very chewy. Perfect to dip into the soup and stew. 

Will definitely want to come back and order delivery during some cold rainy night.
author: Shen Q.

description:
So so good. Yelp brings me to places like this that I would never look to go to on my own.

Went here recently after a nice jog and was greeted by the nice owner. 

I elected to go with the lamb lunch special which was around $14 I believe along with a cup/bowl of lentil soup. Both items were very delicious and hearty/generous portions. The owner himself was very kind and I was able to pay via debit card via Square dongle on his phone. 

This is in the Tenderloin so be aware of your surroundings. Like I mentioned in another review it is worth mentioning because although it doesn't bother me I know it does bother some colleagues/friends who I've gone out to dinner/lunch with depending on the time of day.
author: Rod M.

description:
FOOD IS SOOOOOOOOOO GOOD!!!
Yes! Definitely a hidden gym of Yemini food in San Francisco. I went inside and didn't see any non-Arabis. Staff is very nice and friendly and suggest us to try fatteh and some other dish that has cooked lamb and vegetable in the rice. It was soooo delicious. Fatteh is definitely the most flavorful middle eastern food I've ever had. Very flavorful, served piping hot, comes with a chili sauce (super super hot chili sauce, so go easy on that). Next time I'll go there and order 2 Fatteh for myself. A must try spot.
author: Sumbal A.

description:
I'm always on the lookout for small businesses to support, so when my buddy suggested we catch up over lunch at Yemen Kitchen, I was totally game.  I've always been curious about my Yemenese colleagues heritage so what better way to explore that curiosity than over a great meal?

I ordered the roasted lamb plate, which came with veggies and rice.  The lamb was on the bone, but had been slow-cooked for so long that it was practically sliding off into tender, gelatinous pieces.  The rice and veggies were flavorful and cooked perfectly as well, and the plate as a whole was outstanding at just $14 for the lunch special.

This is a true hole-in-the-wall, in the heart of the TL.  While I wouldn't venture here for dinner at night, I was extremely happy with the quality of the meal and the service with a smile.  Prices are relatively high for the neighborhood, but totally reasonable considering that the lunch portions were so healthy.  I'll definitely be dragging my colleagues out here soon and compare the flavors with the flavors of my Yemenese buddy's home.

Food: 10/10

Service: 8/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
I just died and went to Yemen.

I stumbled upon this location by yelping for hummus close to work. I was famished and ordered a few items upon arriving. I was asked if I was dining in or taking out. If you dine in, you get to help yourself to some sweet hot tea. 

The first taste of tea reached my tongue and I immediately felt this sense of happiness. It was perfectly sweetened and tasted like a great treat to finish my meal with. We then sat for about 20 minutes waiting for our lamb and veggies, fava beans, hummus, and tawa bread. I started to complain a little about the long wait. 

The food arrived and I immediately told myself, I will wait over and over again for this scrumptious meal. The lamb was not gamey, but instead deliciously tender and full of flavor. I was even able to pull out some of the bone marrow (salivating as I write this review). The fava beans had the best texture any smashed fava bean could possibly have. The hummus came out completely fresh. It was as if they just blended it right there and added the right amount of olive oil and paprika to it. And the bread, oh man, that deliciously warm and wheaty flavor held everything together. 

Back to that tea. Yes. I recommend this place. It is small inside, but it is delicious.
author: Marlene T.

description:
I hardly ever write reviews, but this place deserves all the praise it can get. Absolute gem in a rough location. The owner here is both a wonderful man and a wonderful cook. 

The saltah is honestly one of the best things I've ever had. It's rare that I eat something that just completely blows me away, but this does, every single time. The foamed fenugreek is utterly unique both in terms of flavor and texture. Order it with the tawah and you have enough to feed two, or for two meals for a single person.

The other menu items are excellent as well. I never fail to leave this place without a big smile on my face. Eating here restores your faith in humanity.
author: Andrew W.

description: Great restaurant, had the lamb and rice. Lamb was very tender and food was made fresh!
author: Satish P.

description:
I tried the roasted lamb everyone talks about. Given the reviews, I thought it would knock my ankle socks off. However, I wasn't blown away by the flavor- it could've used more seasoning. 

The bread (tawah) was the best part. The hummus is solid. 

I appreciate the friendly service and free tea. There's limited seating in this small place (about 10 seats). I would recommend doing take-out. 

It's nice seeing these small businesses, and I wish Yemen Kitchen much success.
author: Joanna L.

description: Delicious home-style meals prepared by Chef Abdul. Try the lamb kabsaah, a generous portion of tender lamb over rice. The cilantro sauce is prepared fresh and the Yemeni bread is baked daily. Gracious hospitality and fine food.
author: Sarah P.

description: Wooooow delicious delicious delicious delicious .. but the place is very simple and the service was good perfect choice for lunch or dinner
author: Nora A.

description: I had never tried Yemen food before, but this place was delicious! I got the Saltah, because I heard it was a traditional Yemen dish and I was not disappointed. It is a stewed lamb dish and the flavor is amazing. It stayed hot for a long time and it tasted better with each bite. The complementary tea was also delicious. Not to mention the owner is super sweet, I will definitely be back!
author: Alexis V.

description:
I found Yemen Kitchen in one of the weekly local Yelp mailers and as I had not had Yemeni food I decided to give it a try. A quick search showed that Salta ($10) is the nation dish of Yemen so I decided to get that using the ordering functionality on Yelp. Yemen Kitchen is located in the heart of the hood so after crossing two homeless colonies I landed there after almost 30 minutes.

For starters I was completely ignored even though I was standing right in front of the payment register. The cook and his helper both saw my presence but chose to ignore me and continued to complete the order that they were working on. After standing for a couple of minutes I sat on one of the stools. After about 10 minutes I was finally attended to and was made to wait another 10 minutes for my order to be made.

Salta is supposed to be vegetables and roasted lamb that are cooked in a pot, topped with whipped fenugreek. The dish that I got seemed to match the description. The issue was that it was almost tasteless. The lack of seasoning was not balanced with the appropriate use of spices. The lamb also seemed to have been overcooked making it stringy. Along with the salta I was provided 2 store bought pita bread that they did not even bother to heat up before giving to me. Look I agree I'd never had salta before but this just did not feel right. My hunch was proven right when I tried the salta from Yemeni Restaurant, which was a lot better than what I got here.

After the lackluster taste of the salta I decided to give Yemen Kitchen another change and this time got the Zanbaka Dinner ($10.00) which is fava beans and ground beef. After ordering it was literally an action replay of the last time, preparation started after I reached even though I had ordered ahead. The food was bland, but this time I was prepared so a tiny sprinkling of salt did the trick. Yet again I got the crappy store bought pita bread. The Zanbaka after proper seasoning was much better than the salta but still not a great dish.

If I had not had Yemeni Restaurant to do an apple-to-apple comparison I would have probably rated Yemen Kitchen a lot higher, but having made the comparison, the best that I can do is A-OK. I'm more inclined to go to Yemeni Restaurant whose food is similarly priced but is a lot better when I'm in the mood for Yemeni food.
author: Ahmad J.

description: Great food , Unlike other Middle Eastern cuisine's , Yemeni food is unique. This place is a hole in the wall kind of place, and the food is great. The place is dingy don't expect a fancy dinning experience.
author: Madhu J.

description:
I really enjoyed the Saltah and lamb Kabsaah I ordered to take out. Both had extremely tender and flavorful lamb. I enjoyed the spice and the slight bitterness from the fenugreek in the saltah, and appreciated that the stew had a thick, rich, meaty gravy. With all the flavor going on it would have been easy to skimp on the stock, but they did not.
The Kabsaah was a huge portion of a biryani-like dish, with a lot of flavor, and a lot of lamb. I'll definitely be back to try more of their offerings.
author: Taco T.

description:
This was the first time I have ever tried Yemeni food. First time i went there and ordered Fahteh, rice, mezza platter and an entree mentioned on the top of their menu (forgot the name).

Mezza platter came with tandoori bread (SoOoOo Good), hummus, baba ganoush, banana leaf and salad. it was really good specially with that price,it was a total steal. 

Fahteh is definitely my favorite. I can eat fahteh everyday for the rest of my life. the bread cooked with the lamb in the stock just blew my mind. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

The vegetable and meat entree was as good. Personally I think both Fahteh and veal dish tastes the same so wouldnt recommend it together .

Overall nice people, good service, good street parking. the place feels like home.
author: Kashif F.

description: Best food and even better hospitality.  Thank you for your kindness and for your amazing food.  Foothill Christian School looks forward to returning every year while on our mission trip
author: Shannon S.

description:
My SO and I ended up at Yemen Kitchen at around 9 PM on a Saturday night, buzzed from a couple of rounds at nearby Bourbon & Branch. There were a couple of other patrons in the restaurant, but one table was still empty. A polite young gentleman took our order for a plate of hummus and the roast lamb, both to share.

After ordering, we took seats at a table. This is a sparse place that has no airs about it. The decor is very simple, and there's no attempt at a fancy ambiance. I don't care about any of those things, so it didn't bother me at all. However, even if it does bother you, you'll likely forget about all your issues moment your food arrives. 

The silken hummus captured our senses first. My SO declared it the best hummus he'd ever had. Then, the succulent, tender meat and flavorful spices in the roast lamb dish totally bowled us over. Not a word was uttered as we devoured our food. There was the sound of marrow being sucked out of a bone, but that was it. What a meal! Also, definitely share: the portions are ginormous, and comfortably fed two of us.

For a meal that ended up at about $27 with tax and tip, this was such a great experience. If you want some of the best hummus and lamb you can find on this side of the world, come to Yemen Kitchen. Don't even think twice.
author: Leela S.

description: Delicious food and wonderful service. Amazing hot lamb falls apart on a cold day. Definitely worth it.
author: Ashar A.

description: Well, if you've eaten a wide range of middle eastern food, this place is not a destination.  It's good but not great.  Owner is a very nice guy.   Honey tea is terrific.   It's very small.
author: Shelly G.

description: Omg this place is a lost wonder! I wish I had known about this treasure tucked in the city. I ordered lamb and chicken dish and it was divine. Also they gave me a side of their homemade hot cilantro pepper. Delicious!
author: Nadia S.

description: Fantastic and authentic flavor and great service. The chicken was perfectly cooked and I will return very soon!
author: Jacob H.

description: Allahuakbar ! This is the best food I've ever had in my life. Very ethnic good Yemani food I fell in love with place. The owner was very nice and food was literally to die for. I'm not from SF but if I ever come back this is my spot. I ordered the lamb and rice plate, Adas Soup and the yemni bread with honey . Everything was 100 percent spot on ! Thank you so much
author: Moath I.

description:
Decent food. The lamb and rice combination is some delicious rice and lamb. The best thing though is they cilantro sauce they comes with it. It's an amazing complement to that lamb. 

The desert though is meh. It's mostly bread with a light bit of sweet. It just makes for a very heavy desert but meh. 

They take card but prefer cash.
author: Rohan D.

description: This restaurant is hands down the best middle eastern food in the Bay Area! My husband discovered it a couple of day ago and I had the pleasure of trying it today. It was beyond delicious. The rice, lamb and chicken were cooked perfectly, and spiced just right. We are definitely coming here as often as possible.
author: Yngride E.

description: Ery tasty food with large portion. Very friendly and nice staff. The store is small and doesn't look fancy though. But it certainly gets a five star for the food itself. I tried the Kibsah lamb and it had a lot of tasty meat, maybe a pound or so, with flavored rice! If you are in downtown San Francisco, and like middle eastern/Arabic food, certainly try it.
author: Hamed H.

description:
What the what? how do more people not know about this place? Super hole in wall-ey, Yemen Kitchen is very unassuming and will provide you with a fantastic, basically home cooked-tasting meal. I don't think I had ever eaten Yemeni food prior to this, but so much of the food here reminded me of Indian food and meals in the way that you get when you go to someone's house and their parents cook you food. It was so good!

I highly recommend getting their Fava Bean sandwich, Yemeni Bread (Tawah), we had some sort of lentil soup that was fantastic, hummus, and a vegetable stew. All SO good. This is one place that I would be really excited to take anyone who doesn't really like eating at restaurants to, as I felt the food was perfect.

Can't wait to come back the next time I'm in SF!
author: Sruthi S.

description: I used to love this place, but don't bother. They're on a downward slide. I ordered through Grubhub, but called the restaurant to ask for extra condiments. My order was an hour late and didn't include any of the sauce I was assured would be there. Had to spend an hour in chat with Grubhub to get any satisfaction. My advice? Try a place that actually cares.
author: Gary B.

description: This is probably my best middle east restaurant in San Francisco. Today I prefer to eat boiled lamb with rice . I checked near me i found Yemen Kitchen. I placed an order lamb khabsa togo and some boiled vegetables and fried chicken. Food was really cooked well and delicious. I would like to eat there . They have a good taste in their foods .
author: Saeed A.

description:
Yemen Kitchen is the best place to get lamb in town, period.

We ordered the roasted lamb, and we did well. The portions are YUGE. We (two hungry average-sized folks) couldn't finish this single dish (picture with my hand for scale).

The lamb was very tender. It was fatty, juicy and very flavorful. It comes with vegetables and a side of rice or bread. As I mentioned earlier you will receive a very large amount of meat if you pick that dish, so be aware!

The neighborhood is definitely not fancy and the restaurant only has two tables. Therefore, you should probably plan a trip to take your food to go and come back home or find a nice spot to enjoy this delicious meat!
author: Nicolas E.

description:
If Donald Trump were to eat at this place, I think he would cross Yemen off the travel ban list.  He would find the food to be so good that he would encourage the emigration of Yemeni chefs to the United States.

A small group of us came here during our lunch break of a conference at a nearby hotel.  I had the reviews that described it a small, downscale place in the Tenderloin, but fortunately my two lovely companions (lucky me) were up for a culinary adventure.  The walk here in the midday really isn't bad at all.

Yes, it is small - very small.  There is a table that seats two, a table for four, a table for about six, and a couple seats at the counter.  If you're here on your own, expect to have new dining companions.

We started our meal with Yemeni bread and hummus and absolutely loved it.  Yemeni bread is a flatbread, served hot, that is perfect for dipping in the smooth, creamy hummus.  My companions split an order of the lamb aqdah, which was a smart move because the dish was huge.  I tried some of it and found the lamb to be tender and flavorful and the vegetables to be a nice complement to the meat.  I had the saltah, which I was told is sort of traditional or national dish of Yemen.  It's a kind of soup or stew made with lamb in a spicy broth topped with fenugreek.  I was warned that the fenugreek could make the saltah taste bitter, but I didn't notice it at all.  It was delicious.  I almost came back the next day for another serving but decide to try a nearby falafel stand instead.

We were all very pleased with our meal.  Admittedly, I don't have a frame of reference for Yemeni food, but I know what I like, and I liked this place a lot.  I will definitely be back to try some of their other offerings.
author: Lee L.

description: Great food. Great service. They're also extremely accommodating to Vegans. Something for everyone. Great portions.
author: Gigi R.

description: I'm not a Yemeni food officianado, but I know what I like.  Small place. Lots of TLC from the owner. Most expensive item?  $17 for roasted lamb.  But, be sure to save room for the Maasoob for dessert. Comfort food at its finest. We will be back.
author: Jim M.

description:
Went to Yemen Kitchen for dinner.  It was kinda a last minute choice for me since I was kinda nearby coming back from the Presidio by walking.

It's a tiny place about 12 seats.  Customer gave me tips on what to order but I didn't get them this time.

I picked:

lentil soup $3 - good size serving of lentil soup.  I liked it.

Yemeni bread $3 - it looked good, tasted thin and chewy.  I liked it.

Hummus $5 - small plate full with some olive oil and herb on the top.  It's creamy, not enough garlic for me.

Ask for the green hot salsa - makes it all better!

Charged it.  Lady next to me had a Groupon deal so I need to look for it online.  She got the Lamb & Veggie dish I want to try next time.

Some kind of Mango custard dessert $5 looked good too.

Hrs:
Daily 10am-10pm
author: Ann L.

description:
I think calling this place a 'diamond in the rough' would be a bit of an overstatement. Let's just call it a 'rhinestone in the rough' because owner Abdul Al Rammah's dishes represent straight-up comfort food by way of Yemen. It was satisfying, no-frills fare well executed. Getting here can be a bit of a challenge for the uninitiated in the Tenderloin as it is indeed in the thick of the neighborhood on Jones Street. A small spot, it was formerly Brooklyn Pizza, and in fact the big sign in front still says so which likely confuses potential customers (photo:  http://bit.ly/1WiMUsU). Inside is a bit sparse with just three worn formica tables for seating. Two were already taken, so I sat down at the last one available.

Meanwhile, I considered the sixteen-item menu (photo: http://bit.ly/1O7MeAH). Without much thought, I went for the most expensive dish they prepare, the $16 Roasted Lamb with Rice, but first the friendly server offered me a complementary bowl of their Lentil Soup which was warm, thick and clearly homemade (photo: http://bit.ly/1PtlnmF). The main dish arrived soon afterward, and it was a huge serving of tender roasted lamb, two large shanks resting on quite a large bed of rice with a simple salad of lettuce and tomatoes (photo: http://bit.ly/1TYllGF). I believe this would be called 'madi' in Yemen and served at holiday celebrations. It was no holiday for me walking over here, but coming back is an option I'm willing to consider.

FOOD - 4 stars...hearty comfort food that shows Yemeni like their lamb
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...not much on decor or comfort but it's clean
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...they looked genuinely happy to see a new customer outside their immediate community
TOTAL - 4 stars...gird your loins and give it a try
author: Ed U.

description: Hole in the wall with amazing food!! I would recommend going when it's still light out because of the area around it, but if you're up for an adventure it is SO worth it. I had the roasted lamb and baklava, the lamb was so tender and the baklava was just right. I got some hummus to go, can't wait to try it. The staff was super friendly as well!
author: Jackie K.

description: The lunch I had here was bursting with flavor, served quick and hot, and didn't break the bank. I love the flavors of Middle Eastern and SE Asian cuisines, but confess I had zero familiarity with Yemeni food before coming in. The ambiance is decidedly down-market, but what the place lacks in physical beauty it makes up for in gracious service and rich, nuanced tastes of this exotic land. I had the salteh - like a long-simmered spicy stew - and the chicken kabsaah, which was like an Indian biryani with more pepper and cardamom. Straight-up YUM! Will be back!
author: J. D.

description:
I went to Yemen Kitchen last week for lunch, I must say it was fantastic.  I will definitely be going back for lunch more often.  I want Abdul to open up a new location close to home!

Thank you Yemen Kitchen for giving me an authentic taste at a great price!
author: Jake L.

description: Hummus is 10 out of 10. Same with roasted lamb and roasted chicken. Tender meat that falls off bone.  Do yourself a favor and eat here!
author: Josh P.

description: I love this place! The food is excellent. So tasty. And the people that work there are incredibly friendly. I highly recommend it for a delicious, budget-friendly, quick meal for one, or order several different items to share.
author: Karen S.

description: Me and my bf are chefs and I have worked abroad more particularly in Dubai so I have experience in cooking and eating middle eastern food. I used to make chicken khabsa and is probably my favorite. So when I saw the reviews, given that we are foodies and hunted for some good middle eastern food, I say this little hole-in-the-wall IS pretty authentic.
author: Kia M.

description: Everything on the menu tasted heavenly! Chef/owner is an awesome guy too. You won't regret coming here.
author: Junius S.

description: Best Yemeni food in the city. The fava beans and beef stir fry changed my life a little. Great hummus and pita bread. Yum! And great service and prices.
author: Lynae B.

description:
I thought this place was okay...I had a dish with tender lamb, rice and Yemeni bread.  The meat was nice and tender, but not exceptionally seasoned.  The rice tasted pretty tame, while the bread was nice since it was something unique.  We ordered dessert as well, which was basically a "bread pudding" of leftover bread mixed with bananas and spices and a bit cream...this was pretty good.

Overall, I thought the food was okay, but the service was very friendly and warm.  They had some nice Yemeni mint tea available that was a great way to make someone feel comfortable.
author: Ken G.

description: Another TL treasure!! Yemen Kitchen, Today's choice, "Lamb  Kabsah", Admittedly a little self conscious about the ummmms & mmmms sounds I mumbled while savoring the delicious combination of tender rice, herbs, spices and scrumptious lamb. Friendly young lady welcomes diners.. Definitely a thumbs up! And God willing, "I'll be back!"
author: Deborrah E.

description: Very fine small place. The chef/owner is very friendly and explains the food well. The portions were large and we took food home. The hot sauce is incredible, a red and a green that is out of the galaxy--so much flavor! Go out and support this small, local restaurant. You will be glad you did!
author: Brian A.

description: Great food ! Simple delicious . Hole in the wall .clean and very friendly owners &staff
author: Pratibha T.

description:
Great food and friendly owner. Very affordable. Space is a little tight.

I'd definitely come back.
author: Pramod T.

description: The best food ever specially the lamb dishes with rice is amazing, The chef Abdul  is amazing very friendly,  absolutely one of my favorite restaurant
author: Hussein M.

description:
Great food! The food was really delicious and the portions were very generous.
It is small and when I entered I didn't quite know what to expect. We kind of fumbled our way through the menu and ordered the roast lamb and ground beef with favs beans. Both were delicious and the bread was great.
author: Madan P.

description:
Go here! Delish, surprisingly, given the seedy location and sparse decor. 

I used yelp to order for the first time.  Worked fine!  I just wanted a quick bite and was in a rush so I got Vegetable Stew $3 and Yemeni Bread $3.  Staff (and customers) were friendly.  A customer offered a taste of his lamb.  Which ... I'll be back for.

They should work on the decor - ask family to send some things from Yemen?
author: Matthew E.

description: The Yemen Kitchen is my favorite neighborhood restaurant. I have been living in the Tenderloin/downtown area for the last 2 1/2 years and there's just nothing else like this. The food is delicious, the service impeccable, but what really sets the Yemen Kitchen apart is the atmosphere. It feels like coming home at the end of a long day to a home cooked meal -- warm, hospitable, and made with love. Abdul and his family are dear to my heart! 5 stars
author: Laina H.

description:
Such friendly service. One of those few places where I felt my experience was truly enhanced by the people serving us. The owners were just so happy and welcoming in a genuine way, and made us feel at home.

The place is an unassuming hole in the wall in the Tenderloin. I love it because it felt like an ethnic place that just wants to provide a taste of home to Yemeni immigrants.

This was my first time trying Yemeni food, and I thought it was really delicious. We got the beef stir fry with Yemeni bread. Total damage was $13. The beef dish was very generously sized, really flavorful, and was almost all meat. The Yemeni bread reminded me of roti prata - really good too. We both were satisfied after sharing it. If I had eaten it by myself, I'd have probably been stuffed.

There seems to be a good variety of dishes on the menu. They've got salads, sandwiches, seafood, meat plates over rice, and breakfast items. Hope to come back and try more!
author: Jeffrey Z.

description: The owner of this place is a Master Chef. And a very nice fellow as well. It's the small space but if you can check it out. The lamb is delicious.
author: Judah D.

description:
I don't want to talk much . 
Coz this restraint it's make you feel like home 
Just come for one time 
. And you can experience the food taste :)
author: Zeyad A.

description: This place feels like home. The atmosphere is perfect and it makes you feel like you're in Yemen! Abdul, the owner, is so kind and his cooking skills are ridiculously amazing. Would highly recommend.
author: Kelsey G.

description: Amazing.  I ordered the Lamb Amdahl, excellent especially with the cilantro sauce.  Took about 10 minutes to prepare for take out, staff were friendly
author: Anon Y.

description:
Delicious!!! (Emoji plug in of pig nose here) 

I ordered the hummus and (Yemenese flat bread) called Tawah while waiting for my fava bean omelette, roasted 1/2 chicken with rice and chicken with vegetables.

The Tawah flatbread was so fresh and had just the right texture. Hummus tasted like it was made on the spot. 

The service was also amazing. They were so accommodating while I waited for my to go order. I will def. be ordering from Yemen Kitchen via Eat24 again!!
author: Avant R.

description:
My favorite spot for authentic yemeni food.
 The liver and zanbakah are to die for.
I would give this place 6 stars if i could
author: Ziad B.

description:
I have lived around Dearborn area for a couple of years and there were top Yemeni restaurants over there so the bar was pretty high when I arrived there.
The place: very small, 12 seats + 2 stools facing a mirror
The ambiance: very traditional, warm
The food: Yemeni yes, if you are curious about the food or you're just hungry and want some flavorful chicken or lamb, go there. If you know Yemeni food, you may want to think about your options - this one won't be a bad one yet it's as tasty as previous restaurants I went to. If you go, try the fahssa, it's a typical dish from Yemen, pretty tasty, stew with minced beef and veggies.
The service: very minimal but nice, the place is small so if you need anything you just raise a finger and they'll be at your table.
Advice to owner: put napkins on table and offer silverware - in case. I was personally fine eating with my hands but I guess it's not the case with everyone 
I'll try the other Yemeni restaurants in the city before coming back here.
author: Rachida I.

description: First time having Yemeni food and really enjoyed it!  I tried the Chicken Stir Fry which was bursting with flavor and spices.  The chicken was juicy and very well cooked. Chicken, onions, tomatoes, and bell peppers.   Served with fresh, nicely thin pita.  I regretted not separately ordering the special Yemeni Roti which everyone else talks about on Yelp ($2/$3?) but I'll just have to get it next time cause I'll def be back.  No utensils were brought - haha I like how they didn't just assume we'd need them.  We watched our Yemeni neighbors eat to see how to grab the food with the bread directly.  I suppose I'm not the best to assess authenticity given this was my first time trying this type of food but it certainly seems super LEGIT.  We also had some amazing tea which was sweetened and spiced.
author: Olivia T.

description:
I like ethnic food from Colombian to Burmese, because you get to taste unusual flavors and dishes outside mainstream North American, French and Italian cuisines.

I discovered this little gem, a hole in the wall type place thanks to my good friend Usman Chadhuri of Southern California. Ever since, I have been there few times and each time I enjoyed my lunches enormously. The place is clean, the portions are normal size, the food is delicious and the service is very friendly and everything is cooked on the premises fresh from scratch. Did I mention that the dishes are well priced?

I have yet to go through the entire menu, but so far my favorites are Yemeni style beef stir fry and Yemeni bread. This bread is made of minimally processed, unbleached wheat flour that retains all its nutrients as well as its fiber, and is probably the most delicious bread you can find in in entire San Francisco! Go there early for lunch, because this bread is so popular that they run out quickly.

The restaurant offers lightly sweetened Yemeni tea for free to all its customers and I would recommend that when you dine there, you try their refreshing dessert Arisei too which is very light and enough for two.

The only downside to this restaurant is its location, as it is located in the sketchy part of Tenderloin.

P.S. Tea is self service. Yemeni custom is to eat with your hands, but at this restaurant the customers are provided with spoons. However you can ask for fork and knife as we did.
author: Tamer I.

description:
Yemen Kitchen is just a few tables and a couple of stool sitting by the wall. menu is short.. looks ala carte, combos not seen.

eats: chicken stir fry (10) tax included
-portion smallish, came in circular aluminum pan.
-chicken not juicy, not dry either. accompanied by onions, tomatos, jalepeno slices?
-passed on the bread which was extra $3.
cook/cashier gave me yemen bread later gratis, addressing me as "brother".when he handed me the food. (i first walked in, told him  i heard about his great food, paid for it. dashed out saying i had to look for parking. maybe this had an impression on him or he thought i was loony.).
*thanked my "brother", wished him success in biz.
-food can be made spicy or not, choose medium.
food enjoyable, very fresh

take outs:
-beef is $2 more
-only metered parking around.
author: Victor G.

description: I arrived alone and made a new friend who decided to sit with me. He was friendly, food was nice, he enjoyed his too. If I'm in the area I'd go again. Lots of new flavors to explore here but very small restaurant. I'd never had Yemeni food and can't recall any offerings of this type in my travels.
author: Alise H.

description: This place is fantastic. Really tasty good food, great sized portions and loved the tea. Small place but WELL worth the trip into the tenderloin. A few blocks from the Powell station. Got the fish stir fry and the lamb aqdash (sic) and both were great. Second time I came they were out of fish so they use fresh fish! HIGHLY recommend.
author: Dee K.

description: This tiny place serve the best tender lamb i had for a while.. the portion is big enough to make you full and even take home with you! Price is very good and the owner is very friendly
author: Rami S.

description: Solid cheap eats and friendly owner. Will come back again! Had a huge, delicious plate of filling food.
author: T S.

description: Lamb Aqdah? However you spell it I'm going back for more. Abdul the owner is also the chef Kudos Abdul.
author: Ron A.

description:
We stumbled upon this place last night while on a walk through the Tenderloin in search of good food that we hadn't tried before... and what an amazing find it was!

We ordered the:

Yemen salad - light, lemony dressing, with a bit of zaatar
Lamb aqdah - this is a stew-like lamb dish with the most succulent, delicious, and generous amount of lamb you can imagine!
Roasted fish - a whole fish, perfectly cooked, with a tangy and tasty sauce inside

Included was homemade bread (also delicious) and a bowl of spicy sauce.  Self-serve tea ($2 unlimited) paired well with the meal.

The food was nicely presented, the prices were fair given the large serving sizes, and you could tell that the owner (who served us) takes a lot of pride in his food, his restaurant, and his culture.  Service was friendly, welcoming, and great - makes you want to be able to spend time in Yemen!

This is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for people who value good food and small business more than a fancy ambiance.
author: Oren F.

description:
The food and service are amazing 
Enjoyed every bite 
Highly recomend to visit 
Sure to come back soon
author: Sergey B.

description:
Tiny hole in the wall restaurant in a very shady neighborhood. If you make it through the Tenderloin without having a conversation with the homeless it would be a first. The outside makes the inside feel like a refuge.

It has 3 tables and probably does most of its business in take out. We ordered a couple of dishes - a stew, chicken stir fry and hummus. The person who took our order didn't speak English very well so couldn't answer any questions but the owner (I guess) stepped in quickly and helped.

Service wasn't very good - 2 sets of silverware instead of 3. No plates when the food arrived and when we asked for plates, we had to use sign language to make him understand. He brought them promptly and asked us to say 'plates' again which he then repeated and explained that he was learning English.

The food was excellent and a pretty good quantity and made up for the service missteps. The locale didn't make us expect white gloved suggestive selling but we did want tasty food which we got! The owner came and checked on us and offered more bread.

Overall, if you're looking for fine dining or a scenic evening stroll, avoid it but if you can handle the sights of the Tenderloin and a beaten up interior, you are in for a treat.
author: Tabz S.

description: My friends and I had dinner there last week. The food was delicious and the owners and waiters were really nice. The roasted lamb was great (ask for a piece with the bone so you can have the marrow too) and the saltha was a great recommendation from a regular who was in the restaurant while we were there. We will definitely be back!
author: rachel s.

description: Delicious and authentic Yemeni cuisine! I lived in Yemen 29 years ago, and this brought me back. Tasty tasty!!
author: Eli A.

description: Really nice, small place with friendly owner and staff, and a great value for the money! I'd go back when it isn't Ramadan since the things they have available are greatly expanded. Try the stir-fried shrimp-- it has really amazing flavor!
author: Allison M.

description: You are definitely in the T hood.  Small place with two tables, family style.  Good thing we were offered utensils and napkins.  Had the lamb and rice, deliciously tender.  A lot of rice.  One big plate for two.  Hummus was good .  Their bread was huge, crispy at first, soggy as the minutes pass.  The baklava, skip since it was soggy too.  The party of 3 men before us and 5 men after us all had the lamb rice. A single diner had some sort of soup.  I just wondered if any other Arab single woman would ever come here to eat alone?  Would i venture here again? No.  Up the block, there were lots of guys milling around, drug deals? Not sure.  Police station is at the end of the block, not a single police around.  Just cars and the building.  The lamb was good.
author: Helen L.

description: The food was very good. I got the lamb aqdah and was pleased. The portions are large. We dined in and were sightly uncertain as when to pay. Would definitely recommend it!
author: Nathan B.

description: I want to add my voice to the stream of praises for this place.  A classic hole in the wall--semi-sketchy neighborhood, bare-bones seating, and outstanding exotic food.  Four of us had two salads, hummus and sour bread, two lamb entrees and a stir-fry fish entre, and couldn't finish it all.  The lamb was as tender and flavorful as any I have had, and the seasoning on the fish was out of this world.  While not truly cheap--the two-star price level is accurate--it was a very good bang for the buck, and definitely worthy of another trip.
author: David R.

description: So glad we tried Yemen Kitchen tonight! It's one of those small wonderful restaurants you sometimes find and are so thrilled you can't wait to go back and take all your friends. The food is fantastic and the owner is friendly, helpful and obviously loves cooking his home country's cuisine. In our top 3 best meals in SF. We had hummus, roasted lamb with rice and vegetables, fava bean and ground beef, the flat bread, and honey bread for dessert. My favorite was the fava bean ground beef but every single bite of our meal was delicious. Oh yes, can't forget the green sauce. So tasty. We put it on everything except dessert. And yummy tea too! We wish we were going to be here longer so we could have another meal here. If you're nervous about the area take a cab or Uber but eat here. Definitely eat here.
author: Pamela F.

description:
$2 lunchtime lentil soup served in a washable bowl, not a paper or plastic throwaway one. Delicious. A bit salty, but for $2, I was still happy. The owner used to have a cafe in Brooklyn, NY. He was a pleasant man.  Incidentally, the sign outside says "Brooklyn" from the previous restaurant owner, who had a pizza shop. Another guy who worked there was also nice.

If I find myself on that block in the future, it would be worth stopping in for some grub.
author: Kiai K.

description: Exactly what I had in mind for authentic Yemeni food....wish we have one in seattle. highly recommend
author: Tawfik M.

description:
Went here for lunch today and loved it!  My co-workers ordered the Roasted Lamb, which was huge and flavorful, and I ordered the Dihbashy (beans and eggs) which was surprisingly filling and also delicious.  We shared hummus and Yemeni bread (tawah), which were also fabulous and freshly made.

The prices are super reasonable considering the huge portions.  They also provide free Yemeni tea, which is lightly sweetened and spiced and perfectly complimented our food.  

The interior is really tiny, but I actually found the ambiance to be pleasant, due to the Arabic music and aromas of spices.  I felt as though I was being transported to a faraway land, and for a moment, I forgot I was in the T-Loin.

I can't wait to go back and try other dishes!  I have a Groupon for this place, but I almost hate to use it because the food is already such a great deal and the owner is really nice!  I hope this place does well so it sticks around for the long haul.

Try it out - you won't be disappointed!
author: Sarah G.

description: Love this authentic little gem in the tenderloin! Easy to park and sit in little restaurant or take away. The food is absolutely delish! They serve their special bread along with lovely chicken stir fried with special spices and onions which I also put in their warm crusty bread. The lentil soup is also divine! Check it out! You won't be sorry. Promise :)
author: Nanette J.

description: Huge portions and good food. Had the dibashy dinner (eggs and beans). Very nice. Added some hot suace to give it a kick
author: Michael H.

description: Great food! Small restaurant but very friendly and quick. You feel at home while you're there. I usually get the kebab. Delicious.  Good prices as well.
author: Jacob E.

description: My new favorite hole in the wall in SF. I've been coming here each week for the last month and everything I've eaten has been heaven! Yes, it's located in the butt crack of the Tenderloin, but it is more than worth the visit. Every dish is amazing, but my top recommendations so far are the Lamb Shank (if they have it), and the Fahsa Salta (not on the menu, just ask for it)... heaven. What's better than heaven you may ask? You'll find out when you try their tea. And to make it even sweeter, it's free. I can't stop drinking the stuff, usually end the night on 5 or 6 cups. Sooo... just go and find the hospitality of an awesome family run restaurant.
author: Isaiah w.

description: This is our new favorite spot. The bread is the best (so fresh and perfectly crisp and soft at the same time). The lamb kebseh is the best. The owner is the best.  The prices?  The best. If you aren't down w the cozy dine-in vibe, take food to go. Seriously, THE BEST.
author: Michelle W.

description: This place is like eating a meal in Yemen itself, from the comfort of San Francisco. Generous portions, generous owner. I've gotten a free side dish every time.
author: Maryam L.

description: The restaurant is very small (4-6 tables), but it's clean, the service is fast and friendly, and the food is traditional and delicious. I highly recommend this place.
author: Zak K.

description: My friends and I stopped in while looking for a lunch spot after a volunteering event. AMAZING traditional middle Eastern food. YUM!
author: Caroline H.

description: OMG, this place is awesome! Tried their Roasted Lamb and it is so good. Super tender literally the meat just melts in ur mouth. Can't wait to try their different dishes. Diffenitely my new favorite place to eat!!!
author: Stephanie A.

description: Food was delish. Very authentic. The service was great, even the cook came out to great us and ask how it was. Best hole in the wall in all of SF. Great value. Some much so that I'm coming here every time I come to SF!
author: Connor S.

description: Ok this place isn't anything fancy, but the food is AWESOME. I've now eaten there probably a little to much for my own good, but dang it is great. The service was awesome and if your not sure what to order, just ask. I've tried the chicken and rice (awesome), the Northern Beans....great spice. The chicken kabob, great and the lentil soup. This place is very affordable and I can wait to go once again......and while you wait or eat, there is some very delicious hot tea......and did I mention the service.....Mohammad and one other guy that works there were so cool. Will definitely be going back!!!
author: Troy H.

description: This place is incredible! Never had Yemeni food before and have become a big fan, especially of the chef-owner, Abdul. It's like being invited to someone's home and served one flavorful dish after another. Everything on menu looked so great, my friends & I went back twice in two weeks!
author: Leah L.

description:
Excellent service, delicious food.

The lamb Aqdah was very good. Slow braised with potatoes, carrots, zucchinis and other herbs/spices. I liked the look of the fava beans with french bread so I'm going to try that next time.

The staff were very friendly and happy to teach us a little bit about their food.

It's very small, maybe 3 or 4 tables so don't expect a guaranteed sit-down meal.
author: Chris C.

description: The lamb is amazing. Super juicy and tender and they give you huge portion sizes. The service is amazing and super friendly. It's one of those awesome hole in the wall places that you hope never get priced out of sf
author: Derrick W.

description:
Found this place based on the SF Chronicle review. We tried a few things:

Afghan bread - perfect for sharing, and for soaking up all the dishes

Stir fried beef - a delicious medley of meat, veggies and a delicious sauce

Fava beans - kinda like refried beans, but with different spices

Chicken and vegetables - a wet dish of gravy, rotisserie chicken, squash and potatoes

Everything tasted amazing.  We were happy for the leftovers, and were already plotting our next trip here.

Highly recommended!
author: Ellen F.

description: Ordered the lamb and rice plate and roast chicken and rice plate. The lamb was possibly the best fall off the bone lamb I have ever had. Portions were huge and my boyfriend and I had enough for both of us to take home for lunch the next day. Highly recommend.
author: Young L.

description:
I went there for the first time with a GroupOn.  They refused to honor it because I don't have a 
smartphone to scan my own GroupOn.  What kind of business offer a promo and does not have their own device to scan their own offers.  Then don't offer it.  Never had this problem before with other GroupOns.  I drove a long distance to the worst part of town in the Tenderloin.  Thank God for the police station down the street.  I was the only woman there with my son.  Some customers were sympathetic to my plight.  I read the owner is nice but was out of town.  The guy didn't want to call him.  Very unprofessional.  NOT EVERYONE HAS A SMARTPHONE!  The food might be good but I never had the chance to even try it.
author: Jenifer D.

description: I just had lunch here with my brother, it was recently written up in the Chronicle so it's been busy and they ran out of humus and falafel.  So we ordered two kinds of beans and bread.  All was excellent, the service was very gracious. I believe the owner Abdul runs the place and it is evident he really cares.   Beware it's in a rough neighborhood. I'll be back to try the humus and falafel.
author: pochini m.

description: Great good, good prices and a comfortable atmosphere. It's small, quaint, and enjoyable.
author: Anthony N.

description: Been here 3 times in less than a month and it truly gets better and better! The lamb plates are cooked to perfection. Try any of their lamb plates if your a fan of lamb. Customer service is wonderful and attentive. The tea is a treat itself!
author: Angela W.

description:
Found a gem near union square. The food was really good and the portions were huge. I had the roasted lamb and it is was perfect. Moist, tender, with lots of flavor. They could dial back on the cumin a bit but it was overall really good. 

Definitely get the hummus and the homemade bread and try the green salsa! It's a very small space, 8 people max but I think that is charming.

It's near the tenderloin and union square so the walk at night can a bit sketchy so travel with a companion.
author: Nate S.

description: Had dinner here based on Yelp reviews. I agree with others that the staff is very friendly and this made the meal taste better. I ordered roasted chicken with rice and vegetables. It came with a small salad of lettuce,onions and tomatoes. I wanted hummus but they were out. I would go back and try something different the next time
author: Linda M.

description: Very authentic. Yay for the free sweet tea. I liked the lamb khobsa - I'll be back to try their other dishes. Expensive for a hole in the wall.
author: Anwar H.

description: This food is AMAZING!!!! My friend and I stopped here one late morning and left full and satisfied! We got the chicken aqdeh and saltah... Both perfection! Staff is warm and kind as well. Definitely highly recommend!
author: Jen N.

description: Cheap. Hummus is decent. Ful is good. Ask to make it spicy with fresh Serrano peppers.
author: EatVegetarian F.

description: Just had a great veggie takeout! The Northern beans are a must! and Yemeni bread and rice and homemade hummus and flava beans dish. The owner Abdul is very nice. I'll definitely be back!
author: Raoul D.

description: A classic example of a whole in the wall in one of the more dirtier and shadier parts of the Tenderloin that serves the most delicious mid eastern food, tea couple with friendy, warm service. Exactly what you expect from a traditional Yemeni cafe. The place is small with only 2-3 tables, so be ready to take it to go if there is nowhere to seat.
author: Arkady I.

description: I haven't posted on yelp for a while, but I am coming out of my hiatus because this restaurant deserves recognition.  I haven't had Yemeni food before, but am quite familiar with Middle Eastern food.  The food here was amazing and so flavorful!  The portions were pretty generous, and the prices were good.  We tried four different dishes, and we loved them all (which I feel rarely happens these days): saltah, lamb kabsah, dihbashy (beans and eggs), and beef stir fried.  Definitely get the bread - tawah.  I plan on recommending this place to all my friends.
author: Roxana D.

description: Delicious food . Flavorful, hot , tasty, authentic and fresh . I had the Fava bean dish with Yemen bread and my boyfriend had the stir fry fish .I'm coming back :). Owner was very nice too .
author: Lia N.

description: A hidden gem, great authentic Yemeni food! Shakshuka was awesome, I'm definitely coming back
author: Aziz A.

description: Little hole in the wall place.  We found it accidentally and we're tempted to go it.  We were delightfully surprised by the friendly staff and delicious food.  Perfect for a casual lunch.  We will come back again for sure
author: Leo S.

description: Nice guys and the food for me was really good.  I had hamburger and bean mixed together.  It was great with the homemade yemeni bread.  The other diners were also really nice to us.  As noted there are not many tables and other diners actually moved so we could be accommodated.  It was a good, warm experience with a new kind of food.
author: Mark P.

description: I hope to become a regular here!  The atmosphere is easy-going and the food was divine. It is a cozy spot but the owner here makes you feel right at home the minute you step inside and makes sure you have everything you need.  I want to come back and try the roasted chicken or lamb next time!
author: leah r.

description:
The Chronicle article brought my wife and I here.  We had already eaten a disappointing dinner elsewhere, so we stopped by for a snack to save the day.

We split Yemen's nation dish: Saltah, a stew made with lamb, some kind of squash, potatoes, and a dollop of fenugreek froth. It took a little getting used to the bitterness of the fenugreek layer, but underneath was savory, comforting, stewy goodness.

The dish comes with this pita-like bread for scooping up the stew contents.  Very hearty and delicious. I'd totally get it again.

Yummy!
author: Terrence H.

description: I have never had Yemen food before.  We ordered carry out intending to eat later in the day.  We take Muni and did not relish the 2 block walk into a sketchy area in the dark.  The people are so welcoming.  We ordered the lamb roast, beef stir fry, chicken stir fry and the bread because those had gotten the most positive reviews on yelp and the Chronical.  But we were also salivating at the dishes being served around us.  I am a Pittsburgh native,somewhat adventuresome because of it in my choices of cuisine.  but I am not yet to the kidney stage so we passed on those choices.  But the smells were to die for and the food....well most food reheated is not as good but LOVE LOVE LOVE this food especially the rice which reminds me of a favorite find in the Burgh.  Glad a fellow yelper told us about the Brooklyn Pizza sign although at eye level Yemen's Kitchen sign is clearly visible.  I can't wait to return and try other stuff.  I think next time the lamb kabash.  And for those of you like us that appreciate value, with an added salad we were able to stretch each entree into two servings.  We are part timers but this place is now on our regular rotation.  Needless to say, I was not disappointed.
author: Vickie B.

description: Came here on recommendation from other people. It may seem unassuming upon first walking up but the food is fantastic. We saw many regulars coming in and ordered the dishes recommended to us buy one of this regulars. We ordered a lamb dish, the saltah stew, a fava bean and ground beef dish, and the freshly made bread. It was all delicious.
author: Sarah B.

description: Lucky for us many places in this neighborhood are closed on Sunday which led us to to discover Yemen kitchen . . .We had the fava beans with homemade bread, the roasted lamb, and the fish stir fried and everything was delicious and expertly made with love. You can taste it. I just felt so comforted by the smell, the vibe, the free sweetened tea with mint, and the home cooking. Eat here!
author: Summer L.

description: I was at a conference in Union Square and decided to brave the shady streets of the Tenderloin to go on a food adventure. And I'm so glad I did! I ordered the fava bean and ground beef meal for lunch, which might sound absolutely wretched to some individuals, but tasted absolutely divine. I've never had anything this delicious and superbly seasoned. It is, however, quite spicy, so if you're a weakling or fear heartburn (which it did give me!) I'd try something different. I'd be here quite often if I lived closer.
author: J S.

description: It's aight. Where else you going to get Yemeni food though? Meat was real meat. Yemeni bread was tasty. Enough food for two meals. Service was chill.
author: B H.

description: When you taste the food, you understand immediately how much care goes into his cooking! Great place.
author: Leaette S.

description: If you haven't eaten here you are missing out.  Aside from the sketchy neighborhood, the food is amazing!!!  We had saltah soup with Yemen bread and their roasted lamb w rice.  It's phenomenal!
author: ismael d.

description: Fresh meat, taste so good. The rice so delicious and the humus so yummy. Thank you for the great food and service
author: Yaser K.

description: Its Easter Sunday and I'm at work literally starving lol. So, I decided to look on Groupon(Always looking for a deal) and found Yemen kitchen. Had great reviews on Yelp so I figured I'll try it out. I've had Middle Eastern food before but I'm not too familiar with Yemen food. Anyway, ordered the Lamb with Tawah bread. When I came to pick it up, I was offered some tea which was sooo delicious! The Lamb and Tewah were also packed with flavor and Lamb was tender. I'm a lil picky about Lamb, but this was cooked wonderfully! Awesome meal for an Easter at work. I will definitely be back for more!
author: Toni L.

description: First time customer and definitely will be returning. I ordered the chicken with rice and a side of humus with Yemen "bread". Everything was delicious, the chicken was juicy (not dry like other places) and the staff were very attentive.
author: Adriana C.

description: Yemen Kitchen is absolutely delicious!  A group of us enjoyed a feast today and I can't wait to come back and try more dishes.  We had a sublime fish, great chicken and a variety of vegetable side dishes and rice.  The sauces were super tasty and the food was perfectly cooked.  The tawah flatbread is not to be missed!  The owners are delightful and have such a pride in the food they cook.  I will absolutely be visiting again soon, both to eat in as well as take out.
author: Kirsten W.

description: Food tastes okay, but don't order any bread if you're having a takeout order. Got it home within 20 minutes and ate immediately -- both kinds of bread were tougher than my dog's chew toys!
author: Samantha L.

description: I love this place. The food is fantastic (Yemen salad; Yemen bread; grilled lamb; fava beans and northern beans; hummus; lentil soup; tea ...) The owners are lovely, warm, friendly people. The sound of Arabic and the smell of tea waft over you as you wait for your meal. They cater as well, and it's delicious.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
I ordered takeout since the reviews said Yemen Kitchen is small. The Roasted Lamb w/Rice, Beef Stir Fry, Yemeni Bread w/Hummus (ask for green sauce) were all delicious.
They ran out of the Mango Dessert but substituted a sweet honey bread. The order was ready and the staff was helpful with my Groupon since it can only be honored on their App. Food was well packed and kept warm. Trying ethnic food is fun; I will return for more Yemeni food. Shukran Abdul!
author: Angela P.

description: This is the place where great food has been made . I'll be back to Yemen Kitchen again for sure .
author: Ray A.

description:
food is good, but i do not know about the price bc every time i go there he charges way much then the last time, even though I order the same food. 

just check the price on the menu and the price on your receipt !
author: Ricky M.

description: Really excellent, unique food with terrific service. The owner Abdul was incredibly welcoming and passionate about Yemeni food. Prices super reasonable. Great place for an informal, interesting, delicious meal and the chance to talk to an engrossing and entertaining cook/restaurant owner. Hummous and Yemeni bread were fantastic, as was Foul and Saltah (soup w fenugreek and lamb). Tea was very good as well. Highly recommend.
author: Zachary C.

description: Going to Yemen Kitchen is like being invited into the home of an old friend. The owner (?) and waiter welcomed me with such warmth. The owner (?) said, Are you looking for something vegetarian? I said, Yes. He said, How about the hummus? I made a face because I ate too much hummus in my twenties and am not such a fan anymore. I didn't say yes and I didn't say no, but I thought the fact that I didn't say yes meant I wasn't interested. I said, I'd like a bowl of lentil soup and the special bread. I asked for the special bread twice. I sat down, and the waiter brought me pita. I said, I wanted the special bread. He said, Oh, the special bread we make? I said yes. Next he brought me hummus. I was thinking, I didn't order hummus. I was thinking, I wonder if it's on the house because they want me to believe in hummus again. I was thinking, Maybe I should try it. I tried it. It was very, very good and much better than the hummus I made in my twenties. I loved the lentil soup--so chunky and tasty--and the special bread, which tasted even better dipped in the hummus. At the end of the meal, I said to the owner (?), I didn't order the hummus, but I did eat it. He showed me my order on which he or someone had written "hummus." I am not sure how that happened, since I hadn't agreed to it. I loved being there, but I learned an important lesson. If someone offers me hummus and I don't want it, say no loudly and clearly.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: Such. Good. Food. Small shop that serves what feels like really authentic and homey Yemeni food. The bread is outstanding as are all the dishes we tried. Definitely going to be a regular.
author: Fsa A.

description: Great food and very friendly service. The place is small but they made room for us. Very reasonably priced for the city.
author: Melissa N.

description: Roasted duck had a pretty good flavor. It was very fatty and came with some rice that was unimpressive and a small scoop of vegetable stew, which was ok but nothing special.  The saltah was pretty boring as well. I might try a different dish sometime. The bread was good.
author: Silver T.

description: Delicious food at a great value for San Francisco. We all had different main courses (lamb shank, fish, and fava/beef) and shared hummus/Yemeni bread and desserts (baklava and the date/banana/honey dish). Everything was delicious and we left stuffed! The staff was so welcoming and gracious - great hospitality. Highly recommend.
author: Mae L.

description: Cool place walking distance from Civic Center & Market St. One of the few places in the area that's open late and also serves tea & dessert (according to Yelp). Lots of new things to try, without needing to hop on a flight to Yemen! (And yes, I had to look up Yemen on Google Maps.)
author: xmarksthespot y.

description: Tiny place with an authentic feel to it. We had the beef stir fry and on the recommendation of the owner, the fava beans. Both delicious. Bread was freshly made. And the sweet tea was a great accompaniment!
author: Nandita V.

description: Food was fantastic, well seasoned meat and delicious rice. The hummus was really good and the bread perfect addition to the meal. Would definitely go back. It was a little hard to find on the street, but worth the hunt!
author: Laura P.

description: Excellent food. Ordered lamb and the chicken stir fry. Wow! Place is small and cozy, with just a few tables. Tea was nice and sweet.
author: Cass M.

description: Yemen Kitchen was wonderful.  I stumbled in this hole in the wall (sign still says Brooklyn Pizza) after my favorite Vietnamese Restaurant up the street was closed that day.  The owner was nice and friendly.  He told me that his restaurant just got reviewed in the Chronicle that same day.  Great article by the way. I had the Northern Bean dish at his recommendation - very delicious, never had anything like it before (make sure you have them include the eggs and hot peppers).  I will definitely make my way through the Tenderloin to visit the Yemen Kitchen again to try other dishes.
author: Elmo W.

description: The dodgy neighborhood and lack of ambiance will probably keep the crowds away, but the entrees are fresh and original and complemented by fantastic bread and hummus.  Maybe this will remain the Tenderloin's little secret, but I suspect word will get out soon enough.
author: Paul W.

description: I went to Yemen Kitchen after work with some friends and was greeted by the very friendly owner and offered a cup of tea. Small and cosy spot in downtown SF. We had excellent hummus, yemen bread, lamb, fish, and liver. The rice was perfectly cooked with unique and savory spices. Comfy, kind and thoughtful environment - with large portions and aromatic flavors. Will be back for more soon!
author: Amanda G.
